svg.text: This is a well-supported annotation based on robust
phylogenetic analysis and experimental evidence from human
ZFYVE28/LST2. The human ortholog has been demonstrated to
negatively regulate EGFR signaling as a substrate of
mTORC1, providing a feedback mechanism. The conservation
of the FYVE domain and overall protein architecture
The FYVE zinc finger domain present in CG6051 (residues
909-969) is a well-established PI3P-binding module that
specifically targets proteins to early endosomal
membranes. This is a defining characteristic of all FYVE
ZFYVE28/LST2 has been experimentally shown to localize to
This annotation is correct but too general. The FYVE
domain specifically coordinates zinc ions through
conserved cysteine and histidine residues. The more
exists in the annotations and better represents the
molecular function. Metal ion binding is a parent term
This annotation is fundamentally incorrect. CG6051
contains a FYVE domain that BINDS
possess phosphatase activity. The protein lacks any
phosphatase catalytic domains. The human ortholog
ZFYVE28/LST2 is well-characterized as an adaptor/scaffold
This annotation is incorrect. CG6051/LST2 does not have
phosphatase activity. Instead, it is a SUBSTRATE of
phosphorylation - the protein is phosphorylated by mTORC1
kinase at multiple serine residues (S549, S550, S810 in
Drosophila). The protein lacks any phosphatase catalytic
domains. This is another erroneous automated prediction
This annotation is not incorrect but incomplete. CG6051 is
indeed a cytosolic protein (not transmembrane or
secreted), but it specifically associates with early
endosomal membranes through its FYVE domain binding to
PI3P. The cytosol annotation captures the general
localization but misses the functionally important
This annotation is well-supported. The FYVE zinc finger
conserved cysteine/histidine residues that coordinate two
zinc ions in a cross-braced topology. UniProt identifies
This annotation is too vague. CG6051 does associate with
membranes, but specifically with early endosomal membranes
through PI3P binding via its FYVE domain. The generic
annotation already exists and better captures the protein
This annotation is likely correct but too general to be
useful. The human ortholog LST2 is known to be
phosphorylated by mTORC1 kinase, suggesting it binds this
enzyme. It may also interact with EGFR or other signaling
proteins. However, "enzyme binding" is so broad it
provides minimal functional insight. Without specific
This annotation is incorrect. CG6051/LST2 does not
phospholipid) via its FYVE domain but has no biosynthetic
activity. There are no lipid biosynthesis domains in the
protein. This appears to be an erroneous automated
This annotation is incorrect. CG6051/LST2 does not
protein binds PI3P through its FYVE domain but has no
phosphatase activity. This is another instance of
activity from lipid-binding capability. The protein is an
This annotation is completely incorrect. CG6051/LST2 has
no phosphatase activity whatsoever. The protein contains
only a FYVE zinc finger domain for PI3P binding and lacks
any phosphatase catalytic domains. This specific
problematic as it suggests a very specific enzymatic
This annotation is well-supported. The human ortholog
ZFYVE28/LST2 is characterized as an adaptor/scaffold
protein that links mTORC1 signaling to EGFR regulation. It
serves as a molecular bridge, being phosphorylated by
mTORC1 and then mediating negative feedback on EGFR. The
protein lacks enzymatic activity but functions to organize
This annotation lacks supporting evidence. While some FYVE
domain proteins participate in cytokinesis and midbody
abscission through endosomal trafficking roles, there is
no specific evidence that CG6051/LST2 is involved in this
process. The protein was tested in fertility screens but
showed no significant phenotype. The human ortholog is
LST2 is a substrate of mTORC1 kinase and, when active, helps inhibit
the upstream EGF receptor (EGFR) signaling pathway. The absence of
LST2 leads to heightened EGFR activity in mammalian cells
FYVE domains are known to target proteins to PI3P-enriched endosomal
compartments, and CG6051 FYVE finger (annotated around amino acids
900–965) strongly implies an endosomal membrane attachment
BINDING sites for Zn(2+) at positions 915, 918, 931, 934, 939, 942,
LST2 is NOT a phosphatase itself but rather acts as an
RecName: Full=Lateral signaling target protein 2 homolog [no
PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-549; SER-550 AND
LST2 is a substrate of mTORC1 kinase
CG6051 likely resides in the cytoplasm on endosomal vesicles. There
is no evidence of a signal peptide or transmembrane segment, so
CG6051 is not a membrane-spanning receptor itself but rather a
Based on protein domain analysis, CG6051 is predicted to localize to
LST2 is a substrate of mTORC1 kinase
FUNCTION: Negative regulator of epidermal growth factor receptor
CG6051 is likely involved in endosome-related mechanisms (such as
receptor trafficking or signal attenuation) via its lipid-binding
LST2 is NOT a phosphatase itself but rather acts as an
SIMILARITY: Belongs to the lst-2 family [not to any phosphatase
CG6051 is thought to participate in endocytic trafficking and signal
Full=Lateral signaling target protein 2 homolog [signaling protein,
LST2 is NOT a phosphatase itself but rather acts as an
LST2 mediates a feedback loop that dampens EGFR signaling
In a genome-wide RNAi screen for female fertility genes, CG6051 was
among hundreds tested... it was not singled out in the final list of
94 genes affecting fertility (implying any phenotype was subtle or
